moves.1. e4: I'm red, and white takes his first move.
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3: White gets his knight into play straight away
moves.2... Nc6: I mive my knight so that if his takes my pawn I can take it straight away
moves.3. Bb5: He moves his bishop to attack my defending knight straight away
moves.3... Nb4: rather than move it back in to place, or back to block off my bishop I move it out of the way
moves.4. c3: He moves his pawn forward to threaten my knight
moves.4... Be7: Giving up on the knight I make my bishop's defence over the knight known....
moves.5. a3: he moves another pawn forward, this I think is to counter my counter with the bishop
moves.5... c6: I attack the bishop in a hope it will give me time to retreat my knight back to safety
moves.6. Ba4: doing the only thing, White moves the bishop out of the way
moves.6... Nd3+: I move my knight into a catch 22 situation, king or bishop,
moves.7. Kf1: White moves the king out of the way
moves.7... Bc5: rather than take the bishop I decide as my knight is safe for the next turn I'd bring my bishop into play for defence
moves.8. b4: the pawn attacks my bishop, but won't be able to take it the next turn
moves.8... Nxf2: going for bigger fish I put a catch 22 on the rook and queen
moves.9. Qe1: White moves the queen out of the way
moves.9... Nxh1: and I proceed to take the rook, I leave the knight here for the rest of the game, It is one of the factors of the whites loss
moves.10. Ke2 d5 11. Nxe5:
seeing a catch 22 being imposed on me, I move my queen to safety before hand

also this is my first piece lost
moves.11... Qd6: and force the knight to retreat
moves.12... Qxh2: I go on the offensive placing my queen ready for my next turn to check the white king
moves.13. bxc5: leaving my bishop unprotected the white pawn takes it, this is whites second and last piece taken
moves.14. Kd1: unable to move anywhere else I force the king back into it's origin
moves.14... Qxe4: Threatening White queen with mine, I move mine back
moves.15. Bc2: believeing I will not take his queen or giving it up for an attack of his own, White does not move his queen, but instead moves his bishop, for what I believe, to defend the knight If I attack it.
moves.15... Ne7: I get my knight into play
moves.16. Bb3: with nothing else to do the bishop is moved back
moves.16... Qxd3: I take the knight now that it is undefended
moves.17. Ba2 h5:
I move to get my rook into position

NOTE: at this point the game is paused for a few hours due to white going offline
moves.18. Bb3: after a few hours white comes back and moves his bishop
moves.18... Bg4+: after clearing my mind I see that I can check the king with my bishop forcing the only way of defence
moves.19. Qe2: to move his queen in the way
moves.19... Bxe2+: I then take the queen, keeping it safe by my queen
moves.20. Ke1: moving his King out of the way I am herding it into his checkmate position
moves.20... Rh6: I move to get my rook into position, Checkmate in 2 moves
moves.21. Ba4: he mves his bishop, possibly ready to take my pawn as a last ditch to stall me
moves.22... Rg1#:
Checkmate, King can move neither towards or away from the rook due to the rooks attack and bishops attack, nor can it move diagonally due to the knight I left at the begining

A great game.
